title: 106_s1854
content: The Act titled as the "21st Century Acquisition Reform and Improvement Act of 2000" modifies notification requirements. The Clayton Act is amended to require notification and waiting periods for acquiring voting securities or assets exceeding $200,000,000 if the parties are engaged in commerce. The Clayton Act is amended to require notification and waiting periods for acquiring voting securities or assets exceeding $50,000,000 but not more than $200,000,000, if the parties are engaged in manufacturing with specified annual net sales or total assets. The Clayton Act is amended to require notification and waiting periods for acquiring voting securities or assets exceeding certain financial thresholds for companies engaged in manufacturing. The Clayton Act is amended to require notification and waiting periods for acquiring voting securities or assets exceeding certain financial thresholds for companies engaged in manufacturing. In the case of a tender offer, the person whose voting securities are sought to be acquired by a person required to file notification under this subsection shall file notification pursuant to rules under subsection (d). SEC. 3. INFORMATION AND DOCUMENTARY REQUESTS. Section 7A(e)(1) of the Clayton Act is amended to require the designation of senior officials by the Assistant Attorney General and the Federal Trade Commission to review petitions regarding the reasonableness and compliance of requests for additional information or documentary material related to a transaction. Internal review procedures must include expedited review deadlines. The 21st Century Acquisition Reform and Improvement Act of 2000 mandates internal review and reforms by the Assistant Attorney General and the Federal Trade Commission to streamline the merger review process within 90 days. Industry guidance and regulations are to be issued or amended within 120 days to enhance efficiency. The 21st Century Acquisition Reform and Improvement Act of 2000 requires the Assistant Attorney General and the Federal Trade Commission to report to Congress within 180 days on the reforms adopted, steps taken for internal reforms, and the effects of such reforms. SEC. 4. Calculation of time periods amended in the Clayton Act to extend deadlines falling on weekends or holidays. SEC. 5. Additional requirements for annual reports. Section 7A(j) of the Clayton Act is amended to require the Federal Trade Commission to include specific data in their report to Congress starting from 2001. This includes the number of notifications filed, requests for additional information, and compliance time data. The Federal Trade Commission must include specific data in their report to Congress, such as the number of petitions filed for additional information, volume of materials submitted, and notifications with unmet requests for information. SEC. 6. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS TO CERTAIN REGULATIONS. The Federal Trade Commission will adjust thresholds every third year starting in 2003, following the same process as outlined in the Clayton Act. The adjusted amount will be rounded to the nearest $1,000,000. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect 30 days after enactment. The document is attested by Gary Sisco, the Secretary.
